awd_titl_txt: Small: CIF: Foundations of Next-Generation Reliable, Energy-Efficient and Secure Distributed Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project targets the theoretical foundations of the next generation of large scale distributed storage systems, which are currently undergoing explosive growth because they form a critical component of cloud computing.  This growth has been driven primarily by a system-building approach, and the theory is underdeveloped and lagging behind.

This project develops the mathematical foundations as well as practical engineering constructions related to meeting the data-integrity challenges of next-generation distributed storage systems, and focuses on: (i) Energy-aware Distributed Storage Network Codes aimed at optimizing system energy tradeoffs across the dimensions of storage cost, network bandwidth, disk access cost, and encoding/decoding complexity; (ii) Secure Distributed Storage Capacity with regard to both active and passive attacks; and (iii) Latency-minimized Distributed Storage Systems that minimize user-experienced latency through codes by exploring the complex interplay between coding and queuing delay.

por.por_cntn:
We have designed algorithms that require less storage space, network-bandwidth and computations as compared to existing methods of distributed storage, that naturally translate to savings in the energy consumed. We have proved mathematical guarantees regarding the performance of our algorithms, and furthermore, empirically evaluated these algorithms in real-world settings where we observe that our algorithms indeed perform as per the theoretical predictions.

 

In a second line of work, we investigate the security aspects of next-generation distributed storage systems. We have established the capacity of storage and network requirements for secure distributed storage systems. In particular, we consider various threat models including those of passive eavesdroppers and active adversaries, and obtain sharp results on the capacities of secure systems. In addition, we also construct practical algorithms that store data in a manner that optimally guarantee this security.

 

In a third line of work, we consider analyzing the latency-performance of distributed storage systems and designing algorithms to reduce this latency. In our work, we have obtained bounds on the latencies of centralized as well as decentralized distributed storage systems. Moreover, we propose new "redundant request" scheduling protocols, and analytically prove that these protocols can reduce the latency faced in distributed storage systems, especially in the "bad" cases where the service times at individual servers are "heavy".
